content:
The Act may be cited as the "Y2K State and Local GAP (Government Assistance Programs) Act of 1999". Definitions are provided in the Act. The "Y2K State and Local GAP Act of 1999" defines welfare programs including TANF, Medicaid, Food stamps, and WIC. The "Y2K State and Local GAP Act of 1999" defines welfare programs such as TANF, Medicaid, Food stamps, WIC, child support enforcement, and child welfare programs. The curr_chunk discusses child welfare programs established under the Social Security Act, including paternity establishment, promoting safe and stable families, and child care funding. The curr_chunk explains that the term "Y2K compliant" refers to information technology accurately processing date and time data between the 20th and 21st centuries, including leap year calculations. Grants will be provided to states to ensure state and local government programs are Y2K compliant. The Secretary of Commerce will award grants to States for Y2K compliance in state and local government programs, with priority given to Federal welfare programs. No more than 75 grants will be awarded, with a limit of 2 grants per state. Federal welfare programs Y2K compliant with limitations on the number of grants awarded per state and an application deadline of 45 days after enactment. States can apply for grants through the State Governor's Office as determined by the Secretary of Commerce. An application for a grant authorized under this section must be submitted within the constraints of paragraph Sec. 3(a)(2)(C) and in a manner determined by the Secretary of Commerce. The application should include a proposed plan for Y2K compliance program development, budget, and funding request. The application for a Y2K compliance grant must include a proposed budget, funding source, and a specific funding amount. The State must also meet matching requirements to be awarded the grant. The grant application must include a proposed budget, funding source, and specific funding amount. A State awarded a grant under this section must expend $1 for every $2 awarded to carry out a Y2K compliance program. The Secretary of Commerce may waive the matching requirement for hardship cases. Under the proposed plan, the Secretary of Commerce may waive the matching requirement for hardship cases in State expenditures, which can be in cash or in kind. State expenditures required under this section may be in cash or in kind, including equipment or services. Only expenditures made after a grant has been awarded can be counted towards the matching expenditure requirement. The Secretary of Commerce evaluates grant applications based on feasibility and achieving stated purposes. Grants under this section cannot exceed 2 years in length. (d) Length of Awards.--Grants under this section are limited to a maximum of 2 years. 
(e) Availability of Funds.--Funds awarded to a State under a grant in this section can be used without any time limit. 
(f) Reports.--States receiving grants must submit annual reports to the Secretary of Commerce detailing the progress of the compliance program. The Secretary of Commerce requires annual reports on the ongoing evaluation and implementation of compliance programs funded by grants. A final report evaluating all programs funded under the grants must be submitted to Congress within 90 days of grant termination. $40,000,000 is authorized for appropriations for this section for fiscal years. The Secretary of Commerce must submit a final report to Congress evaluating programs funded by grants. $40,000,000 is authorized for appropriations for fiscal years 1999 to 2001.
